unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Condition Failed: Restaurant Ages
question_text:
A restaurant wants to estimate the average age of its customers who visit during September. The manager of the restaurant decides to find the average age by asking the ages of the customers on three weekday afternoons between the times of 3 to 4 PM.
He surveyed $40$ customers and found that the distribution to be slightly skewed to the right with an average age of $62$ years.
Which condition for constructing a $1$-sample $t$-interval for means has the manager failed to satisfy?

choices.text: The data is a random sample from the population of interest.
The data is a random sample from the population and the shape of the sampling distribution is approximately normal.
The sample is less than $10\%$ of the population.
All the conditions for constructing a $1$-sample $t$-interval for means have failed.

solution:
Choice 'A' is correct. The manager asked only his customers on weekday afternoons between the times of 3 to 4 PM. Typically, people at the restaurant during this time would be older people and retirees. This does not generalize to the entire population of customers, as it leaves out people who work 9-5 jobs, teenagers (they are at school), and families. This is known as undercoverage bias.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'B' is incorrect. Even though the distribution is slightly skewed to the right, we can assume that since $40 > 30$, by the Central Limit Theorem, the sampling distribution of statistic is approximately normal.

Choice 'C' is incorrect. Even though the distribution is slightly skewed to the right, we can assume that since $40 > 30$, by the Central Limit Theorem, the sampling distribution of statistic is approximately normal.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. We can assume that $40$ customers is less than $10\%$ of the population of all of the restaurant's customers.

Choice 'E' is incorrect as only the random sample condition is violated.
